Jeremy Tinianow Work About

Seekr

The Brief

Seekr was born out of a desire to make it easier for travelers to have authentic experiences, provided by knowledgeable locals. In the spring of 2015, I teamed up with Nick Clement (CEO), Alia Munger (UX Lead), Catie Czajkowski (Product Manager), and Danny Tran (Lead Developer) to create an experience-driven platform for adventurous travelers.

Details

Client: Seekr

My Role: Art Direction, Visual Design, Frontend Development

The Logo

My first goal was to create a mark to represent Seekr. The logo needs to be recognizable without relying heavily on a specific language, must stand out in the heavily saturated travel market, and should emphasize quality of experience over convenience.

Initial logo sketches.

The script “s” form had an immediate appeal due to its glyph-ish appearance, and its similarity to a meandering path.

Refining the curves & thickness of the logo.

After refining the curves & thickness, I created a set of initial lockups.

First round of lockups.

The stroke variation began to feel a bit overblown. A further iteration focused on refining the contrast and ensuring the mark’s clarity at large and small scales.

Second round logo with improved curves & contrast.

Lockup variations.

The finished set of six lockups are suited to applications on differing grounds and at a variety differing scales.

Color Studies

With the logo feeling well on its way, my next point of focus was on color. My goal was to determine how we might use color to inject vibrance into the Seekr visual identity.

Source material for color studies.

I started with source material pulled from a handful of CC0 sources, ensuring that the material represented a wide swathe of travel-related imagery.

Color-picking process.

Each image was processed in order to determine both the variety of hues and the balance of color. In some instances, there was a final global adjustment to punch up the palette’s vibrance.

An in-depth case-study of this process can be found here. Below are a few examples combined with tag lines.

Example one of color studies.

Example two of color studies.

Example three of color studies.

Brand Materials

Our team determined to develop a handful of materials to express Seekr’s core brand values. These included screen-printed bandanas, custom-printed disposable cameras, and a series of illustrations for digital use.

One-color bandana design for brand awareness.

Visual representation of Seekr's core brand value.

User Interface

With the “why” figured out, it was time to start focusing on the “how” of Seekr. In my case, this meant determining the UI building blocks. We opted for an approach based on Brad Frost’s “atomic” design – designing from small to large, rather than starting with screens and creating assets later.

UI atoms.

UI molecules.

UI organisms.

One of the most crucial pieces to create was the card-based system for displaying information about local guides, experiences, & locations. I developed a set of details panels to accompany a grid display that would facilitate a frictionless browsing experience for travelers.

Web app details panel, experience overview.

Web app details panel, guide information.

Web app details panel, photos of the experience.

Web app details panel, reviews of the experience.

Web app details panel, similar experiences.

Details panels pull from the backend database to display information directly on the grid. Using REST states, our plan is to make these views shareable for travelers, and embeddable for guides.

Photo grid of guides, experiences, & locations, with expanded details panel.

With a set of UI elements in place, I set out to mock up the MVP landing page for Seekr. Through card-based design principles, we are able to launch with a very simple design, allowing 80% of the functionality to play out on a single screen.

Web app landing page draft.

Work in Progress

Seekr is a work in progress. For more up to date information, visit seekr.is.
